en: The amphora was excavated by A.L. Frothingham under the auspices of the American Exploration Society and became part of the collection of the University Museum, Philadelphia. Funding for the museum's contribution to the excavations was provided by John Wanamaker.
The vase is in generally good condition; some of the white paint has eroded.

Side ABirth of Athena. Athena, not yet full size, stands on Zeus' lap while five other deities gather around. Zeus, seated on a throne in the center of the scene, reaches toward Athena with one hand while holding a stylized thunderbolt in his other hand. He is shown in profile to the right, his feet resting on a low stool. Zeus is bearded and is dressed in a striped chiton, a plain red himation with a decorative border, and a short, black mantle decorated with rosettes and draped over both shoulders. He wears a headband over his long hair. The throne has a ram's head on the visible end of the backrest. There is a small, winged Nike beneath the throne; she raises her left arm palm upward. Athena is standing on Zeus' lap facing right. Although small in stature, she is fully dressed and is armed with helmet, shield and spear. A bird flies away from her to the right. Eileithyia stands in front of Athena, facing her and touching her right hand to her chin, her other hand held out toward Athena, palm upward. She is dressed in chiton and himation, and also wears a band around her head. Ares stands at the far right, facing the central figures. He is mostly hidden by the large shield which he holds. It is decorated with a star motif at its center and scales around the outside. Ares wears helmet and greaves. His dog hides behind his legs. Apollo stands behind Zeus' throne on the left, holding his kithara and dressed in a white chiton, over which he wears a striped himation. His kithara is held in his left arm while he plays with his right. His hair is long and is worn in a headband, with long, thin braids in front of his ears. Another male figure stands beside Apollo and is mostly hidden by him. He is dressed in chiton and himation, and holds his right hand, palm open, at his waist. A bird flies to the left above him. There are nonsense inscriptions between the figures.

Side BAssembly of gods, perhaps the introduction of Herakles to Olympos. Poseidon and Amphitrite stand together at the left. Amphitrite, on the far left, stands facing center, wearing a white(?) chiton with red dots under a black and red striped himation, the black stripes decorated with small white rosettes. She has white skin and long hair bound with a red band. Poseidon also faces to the right, holding his trident upright in his left hand. His right arm is bent at his side. He wears a red chiton and a black mantle decorated with rosettes. Zeus and Hera are seated side by side on stools in the center of the scene, facing toward the right; there is a small sphinx under Zeus' stool. Zeus holds a stylized thunderbolt in his right hand; his extended left arm has been damaged. He has a long beard and long hair, and wears a red chiton over which a black mantle has been draped to cover both shoulders. Hera is partially hidden behind Zeus and part of her head has been lost through damage to the vase. Her white face and one raised hand are preserved. She wears a black himation. Above and right, a bird flies left toward her. Four figures stand to the right of Zeus and Hera, all facing left. Immediately to the right stands a warrior, perhaps Herakles. His torso is hidden behind his shield with its lion head decoration. He wears greaves and has a red beard. To the right of him stands a female, dressed in a red chiton and a black himation decorated with rosettes; there are inscriptions above and between these two figures. On the far right are two overlapping figures, the one in front a naked male figure, beardless and with long red hair. Partially hidden behind him is a female wearing a simple red chiton or peplos with a black border.
Beazley 1931-32, 10, no. 9; Clement 1955, 9-10, pl. 6; Korres 1970, pl. 81a; LIMC, II, pl. 746, Athena 367; Mertens 1983, figs. 7-8; Beazley Addenda 2, 77.
